title: An Interactive Timetable of the Evolution of Computer Languages
text:
Language
Year
Authors
Purpose
currentUse




Machine language
1945
(no single author)
Created as the binary instructions that a computer executes directly.
Still the final form that all programs become after compilation.


Assembly Language
1951
Early computer scientists
Developed to replace raw binary with human-readable mnemonics for hardware instructions.
Embedded Systems (microcontrollers in medical devices and wearables), video/audio codecs, cybersecurity.


FORTRAN
1957
John Backus (IBM)
Designed to allow scientists to write mathematical formulas in a readable programming form.
Still used in scientific computing and high-performance numerical simulations.


Lisp
1958
John McCarthy
Created to support symbolic computation and AI resaearch.
Influences modern functional programming and is still used in AI-related domains.


C
1972
Dennis Ritchie
Built to develop the Unix operating system with efficiency and portability.
Widely used in operating systems, embedded systems, and performance-critical software such as operating system kernels (Linux, Windows, MacOS).


SQL
1974
Donald Chamberlin & Raymond Boyce (IBM)
Created to query and manage relational databases using simple, structured commands.
The standard language for business databases, analytics, and backend data systems.


C++
1979
Bjarne Stroustrup
Developed to extend C with object-oriented programming features while maintaining speed.
Widely used in game development, finance, real-time systems, and high-performance applications like the rendering engine of Google Chrome and Safari.


Python
1991
Guido van Rossum
Designed to emphasize readability and programmer productivity.
Extremely popular in automation, data science, education, and web development.


R
1993
Ross Ihaka & Robert Gentleman
Created specifically for statistical computing and data visualization.
Widely used in research, academia, and applied data analysis.


Julia
2012
Jeff Bezanson, Stefan Karpinski, Viral Shah, Alan Edelman
Developed to combine high-level syntax with high-performance scientific computing.
Growing in scientific research, machine learning, and numerical modeling.
